This is just for clarification.  This recording was strictly of a hearing to gather information, most likely without a judge in attendance (potentially one of several such hearings), in order for the lawyers to help prepare there cases for the upcoming trial.  Now at a hearing each side takes turn asking question, to which the other side may or may not object to, but because this is a hearing and not a trial the witness is still required to answer the questions regardless if there is an objection or not, they just have to wait until the lawyer making the objection has fully stated the objection for the recording.  After the hearing is done, the recording is reviewed by a judge, specifically for only the questions that were objected on, or any questions that weren't answered (hearings typically are only for a set amount of time due to scheduling conflicts of the lawyers involved, so the lawyers will try to get all of their questions out in the initial scheduled hearings).  Now once a judge has reviewed the recording they will provide a report to both lawyers, along with copies of the recordings, and the report will state which questions weren't answered at all, which objections were overuled (invalid), and sustained (valid, question/answer can't be used as is).  Now the lawyers then have the option to keep things as they are, respond to the report for reasons for the judges decision on an objection to be overuled (the judge may or may not decide to overule their previous decision on the objection based on this), and/or hold further hearings to narrow down bits of information that weren't clarified in the previous hearings.   Now once the trial actually starts, each sides lawyer may decide to use all, some, or occasionally even none of the information from the hearings(usually only when said information would hurt their side's case).  So getting back to her lawyer's bunch of objections, this is a typical tactic at a hearing(from the few real life hearings I've seen), object to as much of the questions to key witnesses as possible,  and hope for favorable responses on them from the judge.
